metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Tianjun dense soil moisture and Freeze–Thaw monitoring network in the Qinghai Lake Basin (QLB-NET)(2019-2023)
metadata.description: This dataset contains observation data from the Tianjun dense soil moisture sensor network in the Qinghai Lake Basin (QLB-NET) from September 2019 to July 2023. QLB-NET is deployed within a range of 36 km x 40 km in the Tianjun area of the Qinghai Lake Basin in the northern part of the Qinghai Tibet Plateau (N36.9º, E98.96º-N37.61º, E99.336º), covering major soil moisture and freeze-thaw remote sensing product pixels such as EASE-GRID projection of 36 km×36 km (SMAP soil moisture and freeze-thaw products) and 25 km×25 km (SMOS, FY3, and AMSR-E soil moisture products, ESDR freeze-thaw product), and geographic Lat/Lon projection of 0.25º×0.25º(AMSR-2, ESA CCI soil moisture products). The terrain in this area is undulating and diverse, with underlying surface types mainly including alpine meadows (the proportion>90%), alpine swampy meadows, shrubs, wetlands, rivers, etc. QLB-NET consists of a microwave pixel scale network consisting of 60 observation sites, and two enhanced observation areas of 1 km x 1 km, each consisting of 11 observation sites. Each observation site includes three layers of soil moisture (cm³/ cm³), temperature (℃), and electrical conductivity (dS/m) observations at depths of 5cm, 10cm, and 30cm (sensor: CS655). The observation data collection period is 30 minutes, with 48 data per day, and missing data marked as -6999. The released observation data includes: date/time (TimeStamp), soil moisture (VWC5cm, VWC10cm, VWC30cm), soil temperature (TS-5cm, TS_10cm, TS-30cm), soil conductivity (EC-5cm, EC_10cm, EC-30cm), temperature inside the chassis (PTemp Avg), voltage (BattV Min); The data is stored in *. csv format.

background: As essential variables in land–atmosphere feedbacks at weather and climatic time scales, soil moisture (SM) and soil freeze–thaw (FT) are two relatively active surface parameters that are interrelated and interinfluenced. Moreover, SM and FT are significant to the sustainable development of the regional and global water–land–air–plant–human nexus. In the context of global warming, these two parameters are essential for studying hydrothermal changes in the cryosphere. Their temporal and spatial dynamics can effectively reflect climate changes and substantially impact ecosystem health. The Global Climate Observation System (GCOS) program explicitly includes SM and FT as two Essential Climate Variables. The microwave remote sensing technique is one of the best ways to monitor regional/global SM and FT due to long-term, large-scale, and high-revisit observations, as well as the sensitivity to liquid water content and the capacity to penetrate clouds, rain, and vegetation.
research objective: This study aims to introduce the newly constructed QLB-NET in detail, including the site deployment strategy, the installation and maintenance, the sensor calibration, and the characteristics and quality of the in situ SM and ST measurements.
challenges: It remains a challenge to clarify the exact accuracies of different SM or FT products (Liu et al. 2021; Wang et al. 2020), especially under complex environmental conditions, which is not conducive to the further improvement of product quality and restricts their applications in related research areas. Moreover, it is also challenging for scaling research to obtain pixel-scale “true” values using relatively limited sites in a coarse-resolution grid.
methods: The QLB-NET was mainly accomplished during the autumn of 2019. At each site, SM, ST, and EC profiles are measured by Campbell CS655 sensors manufactured by Campbell (United States, www.campbellsci.com) at three different depths. We manually collect data and check the status of each site once a year at the beginning of September (before the soil starts freezing) since most of the area is not covered by wireless communication signals. To calibrate the sensor, we took 109 undisturbed ring-knife soil samples at a 10-cm depth from different sites in September 2019 and July 2020 to obtain the true SM values from the mass difference between the fresh and corresponding dried soil samples.
dataset: The QLB-NET is characterized by densely distributed in situ sites (82 sites) measuring SM and ST at 5-, 10-, and 30-cm depths, with 60 sites in a large-scale network covering an area of 36 km × 40 km and 22 sites evenly distributed across two small-scale 1 km × 1 km networks.
findings: Quantitative analyses of the in situ measurements show that the QLB-NET can provide stable and reliable ground truth for SM and FT over coarse grid scales, e.g., 36 km × 36 km, 25 km × 25 km, and 0.25° × 0.25°. The ground freeze–thaw state can be correctly identified with high probabilities ranging from 85.3% to 100% on two freeze–thaw transitional dates.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to monitor soil moisture and soil freeze-thaw cycles in remote areas without reliable wireless communication?
Example.Answer: A data collection method involves using Campbell CS655 sensors to measure soil moisture, soil temperature, and electrical conductivity at three different depths. Data is manually collected and site status is checked once a year at the beginning of September, as most areas are not covered by wireless communication signals.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced when attempting to clarify the accuracy of soil moisture or freeze-thaw products under complex environmental conditions?
Example.Answer: A challenge is clarifying the exact accuracies of different soil moisture or freeze-thaw products, especially under complex environmental conditions, which affects product quality improvement and restricts their applications in related research areas.

Example.Question: Can you give an example of a dataset characterized by densely distributed in situ sites for measuring soil moisture and soil temperature at multiple depths?
Example.Answer: A dataset characterized by densely distributed in situ sites includes 82 sites measuring soil moisture and soil temperature at 5-, 10-, and 30-cm depths, with 60 sites in a large-scale network covering a 36 km × 40 km area, and 22 sites evenly distributed across two small-scale 1 km × 1 km networks.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'pixel-scale true values' in the context of soil moisture and freeze-thaw monitoring?
Definition.Answer: 'Pixel-scale true values' refer to the accurate soil moisture and freeze-thaw measurements that represent the actual conditions at a specific pixel size on a coarse-resolution grid. Obtaining these values is challenging due to the limited number of measurement sites within a larger grid area.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods for soil moisture and freeze-thaw sensors in high-altitude regions compare to those used in low-altitude regions?
Comparison.Answer: In the high-altitude region of Qinghai Lake Basin, data collection involves using a dense network of sensors distributed across varying terrains to measure soil moisture at different depths. Calibration is performed using undisturbed soil samples to ensure accuracy. The region's lack of wireless communication necessitates annual manual data collection and site checks. In low-altitude regions, the methods may differ due to more accessible environments and possibly more frequent data transmission capabilities.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn from the variations in soil moisture and freeze-thaw data collected at different depths and sites within a high-altitude region like the Qinghai Lake Basin?
Interpretation.Answer: The variations in soil moisture and freeze-thaw data collected at different depths and sites can provide insights into the temporal and spatial dynamics of soil moisture and freeze-thaw processes, reflecting climate changes and impacts on ecosystem health. The data can also help identify the ground freeze-thaw state with high probabilities, thus contributing to the understanding of hydrothermal changes in the cryosphere under global warming.

Interpretation.Question: How might the challenges of obtaining accurate soil moisture and freeze-thaw measurements in complex environmental conditions influence the interpretation of large-scale climate data?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in obtaining accurate measurements in complex conditions can influence the interpretation of large-scale climate data by restricting the accuracy and quality of soil moisture and freeze-thaw products. This limitation can affect the reliability of scaling research, where obtaining pixel-scale 'true' values is difficult, thus impacting the application of these datasets in regional and global climate models.

Interpretation.Question: What methodological considerations are necessary when deploying a sensor network for soil moisture and freeze-thaw monitoring in regions lacking wireless communication signals?
Interpretation.Answer: Methodological considerations include manually collecting data and checking site status annually to ensure data integrity, especially before freezing periods. Sensor calibration is crucial, using undisturbed soil samples to ensure accurate soil moisture readings. Dense distribution of in situ sites and selecting appropriate sensor depths are also important to capture comprehensive data across varying environmental conditions.

Causal Antecedent.Answer: Sensor calibration using undisturbed ring-knife soil samples is needed to obtain the true soil moisture values from the mass difference between the fresh and corresponding dried soil samples, ensuring the accuracy of the soil moisture measurements.

Causal Consequence.Question: What consequences might arise from deploying a high-density sensor network in a complex terrain for monitoring soil moisture and freeze-thaw cycles?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Deploying a high-density sensor network in a complex terrain, such as the one in the Qinghai Lake Basin, allows for detailed spatial and temporal monitoring of soil moisture and freeze-thaw cycles. This results in stable and reliable ground truth data that can improve the accuracy of regional and global climate models. However, it also poses challenges in terms of data collection and sensor maintenance, especially in remote areas lacking wireless communication signals.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the calibration of sensors using the ring-knife soil sampling method affect the quality and reliability of soil moisture data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Calibration of sensors using the ring-knife soil sampling method ensures that the soil moisture measurements reflect true values. This method involves obtaining undisturbed soil samples and measuring the mass difference between fresh and dried samples. This calibration process enhances the accuracy and reliability of the soil moisture data collected by the sensors, which is crucial for assessing climate change impacts and ecosystem health.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential effects of limited site availability on the accuracy of large-scale soil moisture and freeze-thaw products?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Limited site availability can restrict the ability to obtain 'true' values at a pixel scale, which affects the accuracy of large-scale soil moisture and freeze-thaw products. This limitation poses challenges for scaling research, as it may result in less accurate validation and improvement of these products, particularly under complex environmental conditions. Consequently, it could hinder the application of such datasets in related research areas.

These processes are crucial for understanding ecosystem health and the sustainable development of the regional and global water–land–air–plant–human nexus.

This involves visiting each site to ensure the sensors are functioning properly and collecting data accurately.
